page.title: 9.10.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will again be working with the quadratic formula. You will begin to analyze how it produces solutions to any quadratic equation and how it relates to completing the square.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Explain the steps and complete some missing steps for deriving the quadratic formula.
  • Explain how the quadratic formula is related to the process of completing the square for a quadratic equation \(ax^2+bx+c=0\).

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 9.10.1: Deriving the Quadratic Formula, Part 1
    • 9.10.1: Self Check
    • 9.10.1: Additional Resources
  • 9.10.2: Deriving the Quadratic Formula, Part 2
    • 9.10.2: Self Check
    • 9.10.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.10.3: Understanding That the Quadratic Formula Is the Combined Steps of Completing the Square

After that, you'll practice and review.

  • 9.10.4: Practice
  • 9.10.5: Lesson Summary

page.title: 9.10.1: Deriving the Quadratic Formula, Part 1
page.contents:
Activity

  1. One way to solve the quadratic equation \(x^2+5x+3=0\) is by completing the square. A partially solved equation is shown here. Study Steps 1–4.

Then, knowing that \(P\) is a placeholder for \(2x\), continue to solve for \( x\) but without evaluating any part of the expression. Be prepared to explain Steps 5–11.

Original equation
\(x^2+5x+3=0\)

Step 1
Multiply each side by 4. This helps us avoid some tricky fractions. (In general, multiply each side of the equation by 4 times the coefficient of the \(x^2\) term. In this case, that is just 4 times 1, which is 4.)
\(4x^2+20x+12=0\)

Step 2
Subtract 12 from each side.
\(4x^2+20x=-12\)

Step 3
Rewrite \(4x^2\) as \((2x)^2\) and \(20x\) as \(10(2x)\).
\((2x)^2+10(2x)=-12\)

Step 4
Use \(P\) as a placeholder for \(2x\).
\(P^2+10P=-12\)

Step 5
\(\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\)
\(P^2+10P+\_\_\_\_^2=-12+\_\_\_\_^2\)

Step 6
\(\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\)
\((P+\_\_\_\_)^2=-12+\_\_\_\_^2\)

Step 7
\(\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\)
\(P+\_\_\_\_= \pm \sqrt{-12+\_\_\_\_^2}\)

Step 8
\(\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\)
\(P=\_\_\_\_ \pm \sqrt{-12+\_\_\_\_^2}\)

Step 9
\(\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\)
\(P=\_\_\_\_ \pm \sqrt{\_\_\_\_^2-12}\)

Step 10
\(\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\)
\(2x=\_\_\_\_ \pm \sqrt {\_\_\_\_^2-12}\)

Step 11
\(\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\)
\(x=\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Step 5
Add to complete the square.
\(P^2+10P+5^2=-12+5^2\)

Step 6
Write the left side as a squared factor.
\((P+5)^2=-12+5^2\)

Step 7
Find the square root of the expression on the right.
\(P+5= \pm \sqrt {-12+5^2}\)

Step 8
Subtract 5 from both sides to isolate.
\(P=-5 \pm \sqrt {-12+5^2}\)

Step 9
Rearrange the expression under the square root sign.
\(P=-5 \pm \sqrt {5^2-12}\)

Step 10
Re-substitute \(2x\) for \(P\).
\(2x=-5 \pm \sqrt {5^2-12}\)

Step 11
Divide each side by 2 to isolate \(x\).
\(x=\frac{-5 \pm \sqrt{5^2-12}}{2}\)


  1. Explain how the solution is related to the quadratic formula.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The numbers in the solution are the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) in the original equation, \(x^2+5x+3=0\), which is in the form of \(ax^2+bx+c=0\). The -5 is \(-b\). The \(5^2\) is \(b^2\). The 12, which is \(4(3)(1)\), is the value of \(4ac\). The \(a\) in the original equation is 1, and \(2(1)\) is 2, which is the number in the denominator in the solution.

page.title: 9.10.1: Self Check
page.contents:
After completing the square, Odem used the following steps when deriving the quadratic formula.

\(x^2+8x+16= -11+16\)
\(x^2+8x+16=5\)

What should he do next?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The 16 was just added in to create the perfect square. The answer is to factor the perfect square trinomial.

answer.answer_text: Take the square root of both sides.
answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The trinomial must be factored before taking the square root. The answer is to factor the perfect square trinomial.
That's correct! Check yourself: After completing the square and adding the new value to both sides, factor the trinomial.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: The square only needs to be completed once to create a perfect square trinomial. The answer is to factor the perfect square trinomial.

page.title: 9.10.1: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Deriving the Quadratic Formula Using an Example

Here is another example that goes through the process of deriving the quadratic formula:

Original equation
\(x^2+7x+4=0\)

Step 1
Multiply each side by 4. This helps us avoid some tricky fractions. (In general, multiply each side of the equation by 4 times the coefficient of the \(x^2\) term. In this case, that is just 4 times 1, which is 4.)
\(4x^2+28x+16=0\)

Step 2
Subtract 16 from each side.
\(4x^2+28x=-16\)

Step 3
Rewrite.
\(4x^2\) as \((2x)^2\) and \(28x\) as \(14(2x)\)
\((2x)^2+14(2x)=-16\)

Step 4
Use \(P\) as a placeholder for \(2x\).
\(P^2+14P=-16\)

Step 5
Add to complete the square.
\(P^2+14P+7^2=-16+7^2\)

Step 6
Write the left side as a squared factor.
\((P+7)^2=-16+7^2\)

Step 7
Find the square root of the expression on the right.
\(P+7= \pm \sqrt{-16+7^2}\)

Step 8
Subtract 7 from both sides to isolate.
\(P=-7 \pm \sqrt{-16+7^2}\)

Step 9
Rearrange the expression under the square root sign.
\(P=-7 \pm \sqrt{7^2-16}\)

Step 10
Re-substitute \(2x\) for \(P\).
\(2x=-7 \pm \sqrt{7^2-16}\)

Step 11
Divide each side by 2 to isolate \(x\).
\(x=\frac{-7 \pm \sqrt{7^2-16}}{2}\)

Notice the original equation, \(y=x^2+7x+4\), has \(a=1\), \(b=7\), \(c=4\), and the last step is of the form \(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\), which is the quadratic formula.

Try It: Deriving the Quadratic Formula Using an Example

Jaiden was deriving the quadratic formula from the quadratic \(x^2+11x+5=0\). What is the step after the step shown below?

\((x+\frac{11}{2})^2=\frac{11^2-4(1)(5)}{4(1)}\)

\((x+\frac{11}{2})^2=\frac{121-20}{4}\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the next step:

To isolate \(x\), take the square root of both sides:

\(\sqrt{(x+\frac{11}{2})^2}=\sqrt{\frac{121-20}{4}}\)

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.10.2: Deriving the Quadratic Formula, Part 2
page.contents:
Activity

Here is one way to make sense of how the quadratic formula came about. Study the derivation until you can explain what happened in each step. Write down your explanation for each step.

Original equation
\(ax^2+bx+c=0\)

Step 1
\(4a^2x^2+4abx+4ac=0\)

Step 2
\(4a^2x^2+4abx=-4ac\)

Step 3
\((2ax)^2+2b(2ax)=-4ac\)

Step 4
\(M^2+2bM=-4ac\)

Step 5
\(M^2+2bM+b^2=-4ac+b^2\)

Step 6
\((M+b)^2=b^2-4ac\)

Step 7
\(M+b= \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}\)

Step 8
\(M=-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}\)

Step 9
\(2ax=-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}\)

Step 10
\(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\)

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

Original equation
\(ax^2+bx+c=0\)

Step 1
Multiply by \(4a\) so the coefficient of \(x^2\) is a perfect square.
\(4a^2x^2+4abx+4ac=0\)

Step 2
Isolate the constant term to the right.
\(4a^2x^2+4abx=-4ac\)

Step 3
Write the squared term as (something)\(^2\).
Write the linear term as \(2b \;\cdot\) (something).
\((2ax)^2+2b(2ax)=-4ac\)

Step 4
Use \(M\) as the placeholder for \(2ax\).
\(M^2+2bM=-4ac\)

Step 5
Add \(b^2\) to complete the square.
\(M^2+2bM+b^2=-4ac+b^2\)

Step 6
Write the left side as a squared factor and commute the terms on the right.
\((M+b)^2=b^2-4ac\)

Step 7
Find the square roots of the expression on the right.
\(M+b= \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}\)

Step 8
Subtract \(b\) to isolate \(M\).
\(M=-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}\)

Step 9
Replace \(M\) with \(2ax\).
\(2ax=-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}\)

Step 10
Divide both sides by \(2a\) to isolate \(x\).
\(x= \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\)


Extending Your Thinking

Here is another way to derive the quadratic formula by completing the square.

  • First, divide each side of the equation \(ax^2+bx+c=0\) by \(a\) to get \(x^2+\frac{b}{a}x+\frac{c}{a}=0\).
  • Then, complete the square for \(x^2+\frac{b}{a}x+\frac{c}{a}=0\).

In problems 1–10, briefly explain what happens in each step by answering the question.

Original equation
\(x^2+\frac{b}{a}x+\frac{c}{a}=0\)

  1. Step 1
    What constant should be subtracted from both sides?

Enter the constant.

Compare your answer:

\(-\frac{c}{a}\)

Now the equation looks like

\(x^2+\frac{b}{a}x= -\frac{c}{a}\).

  1. Step 2
    What constant do we need to add to both sides to complete the square?

Enter the constant.

Compare your answer:

\((\frac{b}{2a})^2\)

To complete the square, we add it to both sides. Now the equation looks like

\(x^2+2(\frac{b}{2a})x+(\frac{b}{2a})^2= -\frac{c}{a}+(\frac{b}{2a})^2\).

  1. Step 3
    Now we can complete the square. What is the binomial that is squared on the left side?

Enter the binomial.

Compare your answer:

\(x+\frac{b}{2a}\)

Now the equation looks like
\((x+\frac{b}{2a})^2= -\frac{c}{a}+\frac{b^2}{4a^2}\).

  1. Step 4
    Next, we add the fractions on the right side of the equation. What will the common denominator be?

Enter the common denominator.

Compare your answer:

The common denominator will be \(4a^2\).

Now the equation looks like
\((x+\frac{b}{2a})^2= -\frac{4ac}{4a^2}+\frac{b^2}{4a^2}\).

  1. Step 5
    Once the fractions on the right side of the equation are added together, what will the numerator of that new fraction be?

Enter the numerator.

Compare your answer:

\(b^2-4ac\)

Now the equation looks like
\((x+\frac{b}{2a})^2=\frac{b^2-4ac}{4a^2}\).

  1. Step 6
    What is the next step necessary to isolate \(x\) on the left side?

Enter the next step.

Compare your answer:

Take the square root of both sides.

Remember to put the \(\pm\) in front of the radical! Now the equation looks like
\(x+\frac{b}{2a}= \pm \sqrt{\frac{b^2-4ac}{4a^2}}\).

  1. Step 7
    How can the square root be simplified?

Enter your explanation.

Compare your answer:

The square root of a fraction is the square root of the numerator divided by the square root of the denominator.

\(x+\frac b{2a}=\pm\frac{\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{\sqrt{4a^2}}\)

  1. Step 8
    What is the denominator of the fraction on the right side after simplification?

Enter the denominator.

Compare your answer:

\(2a\)

Now the equation looks like
\(x+\frac b{2a}=\pm\frac{\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\).

  1. Step 9
    What is the next step I need to take to isolate \(x\) on the left side of the equation?

Enter the next step.

Compare your answer:

Subtract \(\frac{b}{2a}\) from both sides.

Now the equation looks like
\(x=-\frac b{2a}=\pm\frac{\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\).

  1. Step 10
    What do you notice about the denominator of both fractions on the right side?

Enter your observation.

Compare your answer:

They are the same.

Add the fractions, and we come to the result: the quadratic equation,
\(x=\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\).

Video: Deriving the Quadratic Formula

Watch the following video to learn more about deriving the quadratic formula.

page.title: 9.10.2: Self Check
page.contents:
Looking at the steps of deriving the quadratic formula, which step should follow the one below?

\((x+\frac{b}{2a})^2=\frac{b^2-4ac}{4a^2}\)

answer.response: Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This was already done for the perfect square trinomial to be factored. The correct answer is to take the square root of both sides.

answer.answer_text: Take the square root of both sides.
answer.response: That's correct! Check yourself: To get rid of the power of 2, take the square root of both sides and remember the plus and minus sign on the right side.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: In a previous step, both sides were already divided by \(4a^2\). The correct answer is to take the square root of both sides.
Incorrect. Let's try again a different way: This cannot be done until after the square root is taken. The correct answer is to take the square root of both sides.

page.title: 9.10.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
A General Way to Derive the Quadratic Formula

Here is another way to look at how to derive the quadratic formula:

We can derive the quadratic formula by completing the square. We will assume that the leading coefficient is positive; if it is negative, we can multiply the equation by −1 and obtain a positive \(a\). Given \(ax^2+bx+c=0\), \(a \neq 0\), we will complete the square as follows:

Step 1
First, move the constant term to the right side of the equal sign:
\(ax^2+bx= -c\)

Step 2
As we want the leading coefficient to equal 1, divide through by \(a\):
\(x^2+\frac{b}{a}x= -\frac{c}{a}\)

Step 3
Then, find \(\frac{1}{2}\) of the middle term, and add \((\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{b}{a})^2=\frac{b^2}{4a^2}\) to both sides of the equal sign:
\(x^2+\frac{b}{a}x+\frac{b^2}{4a^2}=\frac{b^2}{4a^2}−\frac{c}{a}\)

Step 4
Next, write the left side as a perfect square. Find the common denominator of the right side and write it as a single fraction:
\((x+\frac{b}{2a})^2=\frac{b^2−4ac}{4a^2}\)

Step 5
Now, use the square root property, which gives:

\(x+\frac b{2a}=\pm\sqrt{\frac{b^2-4ac}{4a^2}}\)

\(x+\frac b{2a}=\frac{\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\)

Step 6
Finally, add \(-\frac{b}{2a}\) to both sides of the equation and combine the terms on the right side. Thus:

\(x=\frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}\)

Try It: A General Way to Derive the Quadratic Formula

Using the general way to derive the quadratic formula, find the step after

\(x+\frac b{2a}=\pm\sqrt{\frac{b^2-4ac}{4a^2}}\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the next step:

When deriving the quadratic formula, the object is to get the \(x\) alone.

After \(x+\frac b{2a}=\pm\sqrt{\frac{b^2-4ac}{4a^2}}\), the \(\frac{b}{2a}\) must be subtracted from each side. Then \(x=-\frac b{2a}\pm\sqrt{\frac{b^2-4ac}{4a^2}}\) can be simplified.

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 9.10.3: Understanding That the Quadratic Formula Is the Combined Steps of Completing the Square
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

Here is one solution for solving \(x^2+3x+8=0\) by completing the square, where each step is shown, but numerical expressions are not evaluated.

Original equation
\(x^2+3x+8=0\)

Step 1
\(x^2+3x=-8\)

Step 2
\(4x^2+4(3x)=4(-8)\)

Step 3
\((2x)^2+6(2x)=-32\)

Step 4
\(P^2+6P=-32\)

Step 5
\(P^2+6P+3^2=-32+3^2\)

Step 6
\((P+3)^2=3^2-32\)

Step 7
\(P+3= \pm \sqrt{3^2-32}\)

Step 8
\(P=-3 \pm \sqrt{3^2-32}\)

Step 9
\(2x=-3 \pm \sqrt{3^2-32}\)

Step 10
\(x= \frac{-3 \pm \sqrt{3^2-32}}{2}\)

  1. In Step 2, the equation is multiplied by 4. Why might that be?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

To make the coefficient of \(x^2\) a perfect square and the coefficient of \(x\) an even number


  1. In Step 5, \(3^2\) is added to each side. Why might that be?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

\(3^2\) completes the square for the expression on the left side. To keep the two sides equal, it needs to be added to the other side as well.


  1. What happened between Step 5 and Step 6?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your answer:

The perfect square is rewritten in factored form, and \(-32+3^2\) is rewritten as \(3^2-32\).

page.title: 9.10.4: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. The quadratic equation \(x^2+7x+10=0\) is in the form of \(ax^2+bx+c=0\).
  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Enter the value of \(a\).

Correct! The value of \(a\) is 1.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.10.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1. The value of \(a\) is 1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Enter the value of \(b\).

Correct! The value of \(b\) is 7.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.10.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 7. The value of \(b\) is 7. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

Enter the value of \(c\).

Correct! The value of \(c\) is 10.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.10.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 10. The value of \(c\) is 10. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

Examine the solution method that has been started below and use it to answer parts d and e.

Original equation
\(x^2+7x+10=0\)

Step 1
Subtract 10 from each side.
\(x^2+7x=-10\)

Step 2
Multiply each side by 4.
\(4x^2+4(7x)=-4(10)\)

Step 3
Rewrite \(4x^2\) as \((2x)^2\) and \(4(7x)\) as \(2(7)2x\).
\((2x)^2+2(7)(2x) +\_\_\_\_^2=\_\_\_\_^2-4(10)\)

Step 4
\(\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\)
\((2x+\_\_\_\_)^2=\_\_\_\_^2-4(10)\)

Step 5
\(\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\)
\(2x+\_\_\_\_= \pm \sqrt{\_\_\_\_^2-4(10)}\)

Step 6
\(\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\)
\(2x=\_\_\_\_\pm \sqrt{\_\_\_\_^2-4(10)}\)

Step 7
\(\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\)
\(x= \_\_\_\_\)

  1. In Step 2, what might be a good reason for multiplying each side of the equation by 4?

Correct! Multiplying by 4 makes the coefficient of the squared term a perfect square, which makes it easier to complete the square.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.10.1 and 9.10.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Multiplying by 4 makes the coefficient of the squared term a perfect square, which makes it easier to complete the square. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Complete the unfinished steps, then select two solutions.

Correct! The solutions are -5 and -2.

Here are the unfinished steps:

Step 3
Rewrite \(4x^2\) as \((2x)^2\) and \(4(7x)\) as \(2(7)2x\).
\((2x)^2+2(7)(2x) +(7)^2=(7)^2-4(10)\)

Step 4
Factor the trinomial.
\((2x+7)^2=(7)^2-4(10)\)

Step 5
Take the square root of each side.
\(2x+7= \pm \sqrt{7^2-4(10)}\)

Step 6
Subtract 7 from both sides.
\(2x=-7 \pm \sqrt{7^2-4(10)}\)

Step 7
Solve.
\(x=-5\), -2

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.10.1 and 9.10.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answers are: -5 and -2.

Here are the unfinished steps:

Step 3
Rewrite \(4x^2\) as \((2x)^2\) and \(4(7x)\) as \(2(7)2x\).
\((2x)^2+2(7)(2x) +(7)^2=(7)^2-4(10)\)

Step 4
Factor the trinomial.
\((2x+7)^2=(7)^2-4(10)\)

Step 5
Take the square root of each side.
\(2x+7= \pm \sqrt{7^2-4(10)}\)

Step 6
Subtract 7 from both sides.
\(2x=-7 \pm \sqrt{7^2-4(10)}\)

Step 7
Solve.
\(x=-5\), -2

  1. Substitute the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) into the quadratic formula, \(x=\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2- 4ac}}{2a}\), but do not evaluate any of the expressions. Explain how this expression is related to solving \(x^2+7x+10=0\) by completing the square.

Correct! Rather than evaluating at each step, the calculation is done all at once, at the end.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.10.1 and 9.10.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Rather than evaluating at each step, the calculation is done all at once, at the end. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Consider the standard form of the equation \(x^2−39=0\).
  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Enter the value of \(a\).

Correct! The value of \(a\) is 1.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.10.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 1. The value of \(a\) is 1. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of \(b\)?

Enter the value of \(b\).

Correct! The value of \(b\) is 0.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.10.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 0. The value of \(b\) is 0. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. What is the value of \(c\)?

Enter the value of \(c\).

Correct! The value of \(c\) is -39.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 9.10.1. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is -39. The value of \(c\) is -39. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Can you use the quadratic formula to solve this equation?

Correct! The quadratic formula works for all quadratic equations. Substituting the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) into the quadratic formula and evaluating the expression gives the solutions.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.10.1–9.10.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is yes. The quadratic formula works for all quadratic equations. Substituting the values of \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) into the quadratic formula and evaluating the expression gives the solutions. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Can you solve this equation using square roots?

Correct! Yes, adding 39 to both sides of the equation gives \(x^2=39\). The solutions are \(\pm \sqrt{39}\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.10.1 and 9.10.2. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: Yes, adding 39 to both sides of the equation gives \(x^2=39\). The solutions are \(\pm \sqrt{39}\).

  1. Clare is deriving the quadratic formula by solving \(ax^2+bx+c=0\) by completing the square.

She arrived at this equation: \((2ax+b)^2=b^2−4ac\).

Choose the best description of what she needs to do to finish solving for \(x\).

Correct! She needs to find the square roots of each side. Subtract \(b \) from each side. Then divide each side by \(2a\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 9.10.1–9.10.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is: She needs to find the square roots of each side. Subtract \(b \) from each side. Then divide each side by \(2a\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 9.10.5: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain the steps and complete some missing steps for deriving the quadratic formula.
  • Explain how the quadratic formula is related to the process of completing the square for a quadratic equation \(ax^2+bx+c=0\).

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 9.10.1: Deriving the Quadratic Formula, Part 1
    • In this activity, you learned how to derive the quadratic formula by completing the square for a quadratic equation without evaluating some of the numerical expressions along the way.
    • 9.10.1: Self Check
    • 9.10.1: Additional Resources
  • 9.10.2: Deriving the Quadratic Formula, Part 2
    • In this activity, you studied a series of steps to solve \(ax^2+bx+c=0\) by completing the square and making sense of how it leads to the quadratic formula.
    • 9.10.2: Self Check
    • 9.10.2: Additional Resources
  • 9.10.3: Understanding That the Quadratic Formula Is the Combined Steps of Completing the Square
    • In this activity, you had to explain parts of a solution for solving an equation by completing the square, where each step was shown, but numerical expressions were not evaluated.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 9.10.4: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
